Award.AwardTitle: Reconstruction of Deep-Water Temperatures in the Drake Passage Over the Last Glacial Cycle: Application of Carbonate Clumped Isotope Thermometer to Absolutely-Dated Deep-Sea Corals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposed research aims to produce high resolution, precise and accurate records of deep water temperatures in the Drake Passage over the past ~40,000 years, by applying the newly developed carbonate clumped isotope thermometer to a unique collection of modern and fossil deep-sea corals, and thus advance the understanding of the role of the Southern Ocean in modulating global climate. In addition, this study will provide further evaluation on the potential of this new thermometer to derive accurate estimates of past ocean temperatures from deep-sea coral skeletons. Funding will support an early-career junior scientist and a graduate student.

Despite its crucial role in modulating global climate, rates and amplitudes of environmental changes in the Southern Ocean are often difficult to constrain. In particular, the knowledge about the deep water temperatures in the Southern Ocean during the last glacial cycle is extremely limited. This results both from the lack of well-dated climate archives for the deep Southern Ocean and from the fact that most existing temperature proxies (e.g. del18O and Mg/Ca of foraminifera and corals) suffer from the biological 'vital effects'. The latter is especially problematic; it causes substantial challenges in interpreting these geochemical proxies and can lead to biases equivalent to tens of degrees in temperature estimates. Recent development of carbonate clumped isotope thermometer, holds new promises for reconstructing deep water temperatures in the Southern Ocean, since calibration studies of this thermometer in deep-sea corals suggest it is largely free of vital effects. This proposed research seeks to refine the calibration of carbonate clumped isotope thermometer in deep-sea corals at low temperatures, improve the experimental methods to obtain high precision in temperature estimates, and then apply this thermometer to a unique collection of modern and fossil deep-sea corals collected from the Drake Passage during two recent Office of Polar Programs (OPP)-funded cruises, that have already been dated by radiocarbon and U-series methods. By combining the reconstructed temperatures with the radiocarbon and U-Th ages for these deep-sea corals, this study will explore the relationships between these temperature changes and global climate changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to produce records of deep water temperatures in the Drake Passage over the last glacial cycle, by applying carbonate clumped isotope thermometer to a collection of modern and fossil deep-sea corals collected from the Drake Passage during two recent Office of Polar Programs (OPP)-funded cruises, that have already been dated by radiocarbon and U-series methods. To achieve this goal, the researchers have first systematically examined the potential of deriving accurate temperatures based on the clumped isotope composition of different deep-sea coral genera. They showed the clumped isotope composition of these corals exhibits systematic dependence on their growth temperatures, confirming the basis of clumped isotope thermometer. However, some coral genera show clumped isotope values that are higher than the expected equilibrium values. The presence of such disequilibrium effects, i.e. clumped isotope “vital effects”, complicates the application of the clumped isotope thermometer in deep-sea corals. By focusing on the coral genera that show negligible clumped isotope vital effects, the researchers reconstructed the deep water temperatures in the Drake Passage over the past ~20,000 years, and suggested the increase of deep water temperature could have led to the disappearance of deep stratification in the Southern Ocean during the last deglaciation and thus the transfer of carbon from the deep ocean to the surface ocean and atmosphere. To better understand the controls on the clumped isotope vital effects, the researchers developed a numerical framework for interpreting the clumped isotope composition of coral skeleton. They showed that the source of carbon for calcification and the isotope exchange kinetics of dissolved inorganic carbon in the calcifying fluid place the first-order control on the magnitude of clumped isotope vital effects in coral skeletons. In addition, the researchers developed a suite of physicochemical models of coral calcification to simulate the carbonate chemistry of coral calcifying fluid, the evolution of the isotope composition of dissolved inorganic carbon in the calcifying fluid, the incorporation of minor and trace elements in coral skeletons, and coral skeletal growth. These models provide the basis for interpreting elemental and isotopic composition of coral skeleton and the coral calcification responses to environmental change. This project has so far resulted in 3 peer-reviewed journal publications and 8 conference presentations.

 

This project helped the establishment of a clumped isotope facility at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, which rhosts visitors from the geoscience community for collaborative research. It provided training for 1 female postdoctoral fellow, 1 graduate student and 5 guest graduate and undergraduate students.
